sourceMeaningMnemonic:
The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>old</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>old</kanji> as well.

Note: This "old" does not refer to people. Think of it as "old things" instead.
meaningInfo: Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
readingMnemonic:
<kanji>Old</kanji> things are misunderstood by the <ja><reading>子</reading></ja>s (<ja>こ</ja>) of the world.

*Note:* Come up with a <ja>子</ja> character you can use for all the <ja>こ</ja> reading mnemonics going forward. This child will show up many times throughout your mnemonic journey, and it will help if you imagine the same character the whole time.
readingInfo:
Imagine a <ja>子</ja> looking at old things. A record player. A Game Boy. A cassette player. Kids just don't get old things.

Note: When you see the (<ja>古</ja>) radical in a kanji, there's a good chance it will use the reading <ja>こ</ja>.
